description: New Latin from tendin-, stem of Medieval Latin tendo, from Late Latin tenon, from Ancient Greek τένων (ténōn, “tendon, sinew”); comparable to surface analyses of tendon +‎ -itis and tendo- +‎ -itis but not thus formed; as also with tendinopathy § Etymology.

nouns.description: tendinitis (countable and uncountable, plural tendinitises or tendinitides or tendinites)
